journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part M: Journal of Engineering for the Maritime Environment

title-group.article-title: On the transient responses of floating beams and the role of radiation damping

contrib-group.aff: Department of Engineering Science, University of Oxford, Oxford, UK

author-notes.corresp: Rodney Eatock Taylor, Department of Engineering Science, University of Oxford, Parks Road, Oxford, OX1 3PJ, UK. Email: r.eatocktaylor@eng.ox.ac.uk

article-meta.issue-title: Special Issue on Hydroelasticity Theories and Applications

abstract.p: The paper investigates the free vibration behaviour of a floating beam and its forced responses to transient wave packets. The analysis is based on the well-known simple model of a uniform Euler–Bernoulli beam, in which the coupled hydroelastic problem is solved directly. In principle the formulation is exact, within the context of linear theory and potential flow. The problem is discretised and complex eigenvalues of the system matrix are evaluated, in order to characterise the free vibration behaviour (the natural frequencies and radiation damping) over a range of dimensionless beam stiffnesses and mass ratios. The magnitudes of ‘resonant’ responses are shown to be linked to the imaginary parts of these eigenvalues. The model is then used to study the responses of the flexible beam in transient wave packets, such as the NewWave group.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Flexible beam models have been used in several investigations aiming to elucidate the features of hydroelastic response, going back to the early work reported by Bishop and Price1 and in the research papers on which their book was based. In the years since then, such simple models have served well as tools for clarifying hydroelastic effects, in interpreting experimental data,2 and, for example, in investigating the implications of alternative formulations.3,4 Beam theory has also been used to make preliminary studies of novel configurations, such as compound interconnected flexible plates.5–7 More recently, significant efforts have been made to use complex three-dimensional (3D) hydroelastic models in the design of ships (see, for example, the reviews by Chen et al.,8 Wu and Cui9 and Hirdaris and Temarel,10 and the application to container ships by Senjanović et al.11). Other complex hydroelastic phenomena have also been studied, such as those linked to second-order hydrodynamic effects (see, for example, the papers by Jensen and Pedersen12 and Wu et al.13). A recent assessment of the state of the art in mathematical modelling in the extended field of hydroelasticity has been provided by Korobkin et al.14

Almost all the above work, however, has been concerned with the steady state response to harmonic waves or with analyses using frequency response functions to obtain mean square responses in random waves and statistics of extreme responses. There have been rather few attempts to study the hydroelastic response to the initial conditions and to transient wave events. The response to impulsive loads was considered by Korobkin15 using asymptotic approximations to simplify the formulation, e.g. for very long plates or very-short-duration loads. Sturova16,17 developed approaches for the response to initial disturbances and to an external force, in shallow water or infinitely deep water. In shallow water the hydrodynamic problem can be much simplified, leading to coupled second-order ordinary differential equations for the time-dependent coefficients of an expansion in dry modes of the beam. In the infinitely deep-water case, a convolution representation of the transient hydrodynamics was adopted. Meylan and co-workers18–20 first used generalised eigenfunction expansions to obtain time domain expressions for the response to the initial conditions. Kashiwagi21 reviewed work on transient behaviour linked to the Japanese research programme on a very large floating structure, in part motivated by the problem of aircraft take-off and landing on a floating airport. His paper then developed a method based on a mode expansion approach for a rectangular plate coupled with use of the convolution integral. The application to floating runways also motivated work by Kim and Ertekin22 using the Green–Naghdi theory, and the transient response during take-off was modelled by Xia and Ertekin.23 Malenica et al.24 used a 3D hydrodynamic model of a flexible barge to obtain the impulse response functions (relative to the responses in the dry modes of the barge modelled as a beam), with numerical integration of the convolution terms which lead to the response to the initial conditions. They also performed experiments on this problem. Taghipour et al.25 used state–space models to replace the convolution integrals, thereby obtaining the transient responses more efficiently and accurately. Denchfield et al.26,27 investigated the hydroelastic response of a frigate in a transient wave packet characteristic of a rogue or freak wave. The calculations were based on two-dimensional frequency domain hydroelasticity, and the use of fast Fourier transforms to obtain the transient responses to the wave packet. They successfully compared their numerical results with extensive experimental data from wave tank models.

The present paper is motivated by the view that the influences on the transient responses of flexible floating structures are still not well understood, and that the use of a very simple beam model may provide useful insight. The numerical model is a development of that described earlier by the present author28 and is described in the second section. The frequency responses and the analysis of complex eigenvalues of the hydroelastic model are presented in the next section, and a link is made between the imaginary parts of the eigenvalues and the magnitude of the ‘resonant’ responses. The fourth section extends the analysis to obtain the transient response of the beam to wave packets and presents numerical results for various cases which differ substantially in their behaviour. Some conclusions are then drawn concerning the key parameters influencing this behaviour.

sec.title: The numerical model
sec.p: The linear elastic beam is assumed to be of length L, flexural rigidity EI and draught h, floating in water of density ρ and depth d. The coordinates Oxz are located at the centre of the beam, with the x-axis in the mean free surface and z positive upwards, as shown in Figure 1. The beam is excited by waves of frequency ω and small amplitude AI propagating in the negative x direction. The equations are expressed in dimensionless form, with the lengths non-dimensionalised by L, the pressure by AIρg (where g is the acceleration due to gravity) and the deflection of the beam by AI. The coordinate x is for convenience non-dimensionalised by L/2. The dimensionless parameters which are introduced are
The dimensionless pressure acting on the beam and the deflection respectively may be written
Using a formulation such as given previously by the present author,4 the Euler–Bernoulli beam theory may be used to write the equation coupling these as

where the pressure acts on the beam at z = 0 because the draught is assumed to be small. (Note that the mass of the beam is not taken as zero. Others, such as Kim and Ertekin,29 have considered the implications of zero draught coupled with zero mass.) Structural damping is not explicitly incorporated in equation (1), but viscous damping could be simply included by letting β be complex. Alternatively, a form of proportional damping could be modelled by including a term of the form γK1/2w.
A second coupling equation may be obtained by formulating the boundary value problem for the velocity potential in the fluid, as shown by Khabakhpasheva and Korobkin.5 The result is

where k is the dimensionless wave number and G(x, x0) is a Green function given in the cited paper. Khabakhpasheva and Korobkin5 solved equations (1) and (2) by expressing w as a truncated series of the in-vacuo modes of the beam, and p as a sum of trigonometric functions. An alternative approach would be to solve directly for the velocity using matched eigenfunction expansions in the domains below the beam and below the free surface, as shown by Wu et al.2 Here, we use the Galerkin method to approximate the solution of equations (1) and (2), as in the earlier work of the present author.28
Truncated series of Legendre polynomials are used here to approximate both the deflection and the pressure. Thus
with the functions ψn(x) defined by
Here, the Pn(x) are the standard Legendre polynomials defined in the domain [−1, 1], with Pn(1) = 1 Hence
This considerably simplifies the resulting analysis. As shown by Kim and Ertekin,22 it leads to a system of matrix equations of the form

where W and P are vectors of the unknown generalised coordinates wn and pn respectively, PI is the term representing the incident wave excitation and I is the identity matrix. The terms of the other (N + 1) × (N + 1) matrices are
where the prime designates a derivative. The excitation term is

Calculation of C is straightforward, but some care is required to evaluate D efficiently, using recurrence relations between the different Legendre polynomials. It may be noted that both C and D are symmetric matrices, and D is complex.

The Green function given by Khabakhpasheva and Korobkin5 is an infinite series of functions of the absolute value |x−x0| of the distance between source and field points, having the form exp(sj|x−x0|), where the sj values correspond to the wave numbers of the propagating (s0 = −ik) and evanescent (sj being negative real for j = 1, 2, …, ∞) modes obtained from the roots of the corresponding dispersion equations. Hence, the elements of the matrix D involve sums of terms of the form
This may be written
where
It is clear that Imn = 0, m + n odd, and it is useful to define
To evaluate these integrals it is helpful to use the relation satisfied by the Legendre polynomials30
Substituting equation (9) into equation (7c) and integrating by parts, we obtain the recurrence relation
Substitution of this into equation (7b) and use of the orthogonality of the Legendre functions (noting that the exponential term cancels out) lead to
where δm,n is the Kronecker delta.

At first sight, equation (11) appears to be an attractive recurrence relation for obtaining Im,n+ for successively higher values of m and n, starting from easily integrable results for n equal to 0 or 1. Unfortunately, however, the recurrence is not always well conditioned. One way of dealing with this is to use symbolic computation and high-precision arithmetic. Here a reverse recurrence expression is used (see, for example, the paper by Fox31), by reformulating the equations in the form
The procedure then is as follows, for each value of m. Initial values are set for the largest two values of n, say

The recurrence is first performed using equation (11) for m = 0 and m = 1, leading successively to all the values of I¯1,n+ and I¯0,n+ down to I¯1,2+, I¯0,2+. None of these involves the term in large parentheses in equation (12), but the results will not be correct. They must all be scaled. For m = 0, the factor by which I¯0,n+ should be scaled is I0,2+ divided by I¯0,2+, where the former can easily be evaluated analytically. I0,0+ is obtained analytically, or by the use of the scaled value from the recurrence with the extra term −1/s from the large parentheses in equation (12). An equivalent procedure is then used for I1,n+ and, from these, using equation (11) gives Im,0+ and Im,1+. Im,n+ may then be evaluated for 1 < n ≤ m, using a similar scheme for successively larger m, and scaling with the previously obtained Im,m+. The remaining terms are finally obtained through further use of the relations in equation (11). This method appears to be robust and efficient and, by using equation (8), all the integrals Im,n in equation (7a) and hence the matrix D can be rapidly obtained. A similar, but simpler, process is used for evaluation of the incident wave excitation vector PI.

Finally the linear algebraic equations (5) may be solved, for a particular number of polynomials in the model. The deflected shape of the beam, and the hydrodynamic pressure on it, are obtained directly from equation (3). Other relevant quantities, such as the bending moment and the shear force at any point in the beam, may be calculated from these. It is better to obtain these quantities directly from a force balance rather than by differentiating the deflections twice and three times respectively.

sec.title: Theoretical analysis
sec.p: The following analysis is related to the generalised eigenfunction method described by Hazard and Meylan18 in the context of various water wave problems and applied by Meylan and Eatock Taylor32 to near-trapping by arrays of cylinders in waves. Resonances may be anticipated in the hydroelasticity problem under consideration here, and evaluation of the complex eigenvalues of the model described above can provide information on the frequencies of these resonances and the hydrodynamic damping associated with the free surface waves radiated away from the vibrating beam.
The starting point for this analysis is equation (5), from which the pressure unknowns P may be eliminated to obtain
where

It could be assumed that β is complex as a means of modelling some structural damping, although this is not done here. Q and also D are functions of the frequency parameter K. After setting the right-hand side of equation (14a) to zero, the solution to the eigenvalue problem may be obtained by using a truncated Taylor series expansion around the anticipated pole K¯r, as in the work of Meylan and Tomic.20 Thus we may take
where Kr is an estimate of the real part of the eigenvalue. The expansion yields
where

Equation (15b) has the form of a generalised eigenvalue problem; from the complex eigenvalue σr which is close to Kr, the complex pole K¯r may be obtained, and Ψ(r) is the corresponding eigenvector. In practice, Q(Kr) can be obtained from a finite difference approximation based on values of Q(Kr) at adjacent real wave numbers. Here the simple form
is used. Clearly the key to the success of such a procedure is starting from a good approximation Kr. The matter of convergence is discussed below.

First, however, an approximation to the frequency response in the vicinity of a pole K¯r is developed. This was suggested by Meylan and Tomic.20 It is based on an assumption (which may or may not be satisfactory) that the response at the real wave number Kr near K¯r has the nature of a resonance and is dominated by the contribution from the eigenvector Ψ(r). The solution is thus approximated by
Substitution of this into equation (14a), premultiplication by Ψ(r)T and use of equations (15a) and (15b) lead to an equation for P(r) and the result
Here, the superscript T denotes transpose (and not conjugate) as Q is symmetric and not Hermitian.
In the real wave number space a resonance can then be said to occur when Kr = Re(K¯r), at the rth pole. The magnitude of the response is
It is instructive to consider the analogy of the resonant response of the beam to an external force in vacuo. This can be modelled by the first line of equation (5) which is

where F represents the external force and the other parameters are defined in the same way as before (although the signs in equation (5) are different, because it is convenient there to have positive coefficients multiplying the pressure unknowns). It can now be assumed that β = β0(1+ε), the imaginary part representing the structural damping in the beam. The undamped resonant frequencies are given by the eigenvalues of the problem
The forced response in the structural mode r can then be obtained as

The similarity of equation (19) to equation (22) can be noted, although they refer to entirely different situations. In the latter case, namely a beam in vacuo with structural damping, the resonant response is inversely proportional to the structural damping term ε; in the former case, namely a floating beam with wave-making damping but no structural damping, the resonant response is inversely proportional to the imaginary part of the complex wave number.

sec.title: Numerical results
sec.p: The problem studied by Wu et al.2 in their experimental and numerical investigation is now examined. It concerns a uniform beam for which (in terms of the dimensionless parameters defined above) μ1 = 8.36 × 10−4, β1 = 4.8025 × 10−6 and δ1 = 0.11, representing a small model of a very large floating structure, having a length of 10 m in a tank of depth 1.1 m. This is subsequently referred to as the reference case or case 1, and the parameters are distinguished with the subscript 1. Figure 2 compares their results for two wave periods, corresponding to K = 4.870 and K = 19.713, with those obtained here. They used 25 vibration modes in their matching procedure, while here a series of 12 Legendre polynomials and 25 terms in the Green function series were used. The agreement is seen to be excellent. Some results for three other cases are also considered here, as defined in Table 1. The only parameters that differ between the cases are μ and β.

caption.p: Comparison of results for the reference case with those from the work of Wu et al.2 for K = 4.870 and K = 19.713.

sec.p: Figure 3 shows the results of calculations of the first five eigenfunctions of the floating beam for case 4, evaluated as described above. The values of the real parts Re(K¯r) of the poles are also shown. Each eigenfunction is portrayed through the real and imaginary parts of the hydrostatic pressure, and the pressure due to the radiated waves. The plot of the hydrostatic pressure is of course exactly the same as the distribution of the displacement along the beam, because of the non-dimensionalisation. The eigenfunctions are alternately symmetric and anti-symmmetric (although the expected lowest symmetric mode for this case has not been detected by the present approach). They roughly correspond to the one- to five-node modes of a free–free uniform beam vibrating freely in vacuo.

caption.p: The first five eigenfunctions (the real parts and the imaginary parts of the hydrostatic and the radiation pressure terms) for case 4, with the corresponding real parts of the eigenvalues.

sec.p: A typical example of the convergence of the real parts of three eigenvalues is shown in Figure 4 for two-node, three-node and four-node eigenfunctions. These are obtained from equation (15b) using equation (16) to approximate the derivatives and

caption.p: Convergence of the real parts of the eigenvalues for a typical case.

sec.p: The values in Figure 4 were normalised by the asymptotic values, taken as those for r = 7. Table 2 shows the convergence of the real and imaginary parts of the eigenvalues with the number of Legendre polynomials used in this case. As might be expected, the number of polynomials needed to obtain equivalent accuracy increases with increasing mode number.

caption.p: Real and imaginary parts of the eigenvalues for a typical case, as a function of N.

sec.p: The frequency responses of the beams (cases 1 to 4) in incident waves are plotted in Figure 5. These are characterised by the absolute values of the dimensionless displacements at the upwave (right-hand) end, and the middle of the beam (w(1) and w(0) respectively). The values of the complex eigenvalues (Im(K¯r) versus Re(K¯r)) are also plotted. Comparison of the cases shown in Figure 5 indicates very different types of behaviour. For cases 3 and 4, the frequency responses show very pronounced resonances, each of which leads to a sharp peak in the end deflection w(1). The midpoint deflection w(0) has maxima corresponding to every other peak in the curve for w(1), as is expected when there is a node at the midpoint of every other mode of vibration of the beam. It can also be observed that the resonances occur at, or very close to, the wave numbers corresponding to Re(K¯r). Furthermore, the values of Im(K¯r) in Figures 5(c) and 5(d) are much smaller than the corresponding values in Figures 5(a) and 5(b). This confirms that the sharp resonances are linked to low values of Im(K¯r), which is consistent with the effect of radiation damping being much smaller for cases 3 and 4 than for cases 1 and 2. Note, however, that the difference between these cases relates to the stiffness and inertia of the beam, and not explicitly to the hydrodynamics.

caption.p: Frequency responses for the four cases, together with the real parts and the imaginary parts of the complex eigenvalues K¯r.

sec.title: Transient response
sec.p: In the light of the above, it is of interest to investigate the possible qualitative differences in the transient responses of the beams. Hazard and Meylan18 and Meylan and Sturova19 have shown how results may be obtained for a beam released from the prescribed initial conditions in a fluid initially at rest. Here we consider the problem of a beam initially at rest, disturbed by a transient incident wave train. This could be a wave front as generated by a wave maker in a physical wave tank, as investigated for example by Eatock Taylor et al.33 in the context of near-trapping by arrays of cylinders. Here, however, we are interested in how flexible beams respond to a short transient wave pulse, such as a NewWave focused wave group. This can provide an indication of the expected local behaviour (in time and space) during the passage of an extreme wave in a sea state (see, for example, the papers by Boccotti34 and Tromans et al.35). In particular, examination of the response of the beam to such a transient wave group allows the persistent motions of the beam to be investigated in some cases well after the wave group has passed downstream.
Based on the NewWave theory,35 the wave elevation may be described by means of the integral

where S(ω) is the spectral density of the sea state in which the extreme wave is embedded. Here again it is convenient at this point to use dimensionless variables, and it may be noted that x0 and t0 designate the position and time respectively at which the wave focuses to generate the maximum elevation. At the focal position x0, the wave elevation is the autocorrelation function centred at t = t0. If the complex frequency response function for the beam in regular waves is known, w(x, ω) say, the response to the transient wave group can be written
This may be evaluated for discrete frequencies and times using fast Fourier transforms.
The results using this approach for the reference case 1 are shown in Figure 6, for two incident wave spectra. The first is the Pierson–Moskowitz (PM) spectrum, which is here written in the form

caption.p: Time histories of the wave elevation and the beam response (case 1) for (a) the PM wave group and (b) the Gaussian wave group.

sec.p: where ω is the frequency in radians per second and ωp is the peak frequency. The other spectrum considered is a Gaussian function given by
where Δ is the half-bandwidth. Both spectra have a normalisation constant A¯ such that the crest of the resulting focused wave group has a unit value.

In some of the figures below, physical dimensions are used, to relate the results to the experimental model used by Wu et al.2Figure 6(a) shows time histories corresponding to a wave group based on a PM spectrum with a peak period Tp=2π/ωp=2.69s. Both the incident wave and the response of the beam (case 1) are shown. Dimensionless units are used for the wave elevation and beam response (the maximum crest amplitude of the wave being set to unity), but dimensional units for spatial positions and time (recalling that the beam has a length of 10 m). The value of Tp corresponds to K = 5.57 in Figure 5. The wave propagates from right to left and is focused at x = 60 m, the position of the right-hand end of the beam. The dot-dashed curve shows the typical compact group behaviour of an extreme wave associated with a broadband sea spectrum. The response at the right-hand end of the beam is shown as the solid curve; it follows the wave closely, with little dynamic response. Figure 6(b) shows the equivalent results for a wave group based on a Gaussian spectrum, with Δ = 0.1 rad/s. Now the wave group is much less compact, but again the beam follows the wave closely.

The results for case 4 are shown in Figure 7. The peak period of the PM spectrum leading to Figure 7(a) again corresponds to K = 5.57, which is the value at one of the peaks in the solid curve in Figure 5(d) (the response at the right-hand end of the beam). Other peaks are also excited, because of the broadband nature of the PM spectrum. This may be seen in Figure 8(a), comparing the computed (dimensionless) spectrum of the wave time history with that of the response at the right-hand end of the beam. (The wave spectrum has been tapered down to zero at K = 20, to avoid spurious effects in the signal processing.) The beam response follows the wave during the passage of the wave packet, but with increased magnitude. There is also seen to be a burst of response at this end of the beam well after the packet has passed; this is discussed further below. The response of the case 4 beam in a Gaussian spectrum is indicated similarly in Figures 7(b) and 8(b). This is for a spectrum with its peak at Tp = 1.84 s, corresponding to the maximum at K = 11.95 in Figure 5(d). The response is substantially magnified in the case shown in Figure 7(b) and reduces only gradually in time in comparison with the decay of the wave packet itself. The spectrum of the response shows evidence of small contributions from the peaks at K = 10.49 and K = 13.63 in Figure 5(d) (case 4).

caption.p: Time histories of the wave elevation and the beam response (case 4) for (a) the PM wave group and (b) the Gaussian wave group.
Spectra of the wave elevation and the response (case 4) for (a) the PM wave group and (b) the Gaussian wave group.

sec.p: It is interesting also to examine plots of the spatial response of the case 4 beam at particular times. It is clear from Figure 7(a) that in the specified PM spectrum the right-hand end of the beam in case 4 reaches its maximum non-dimensional value of 1.54 almost exactly at the time when the wave is focused at that point, T = 181.5 s. During the second packet of response between 205 s and 220 s there is also a local maximum (of 0.30) at T = 207.3 s. Between these times there is a maximum in the response of the left-hand end of the beam (a value of 1.15 at x = 50 m), when T = 193.4 s. The spatial profiles of the beam at these three times are shown in the left-hand subplots of Figure 9, together with the corresponding wave elevations. At T = 207.3 s the incident wave group has propagated far away from the beam, but a substantial flexural wave is still evident in the beam. This can also be seen in the space–time plots shown in Figure 10; the propagation of the incident wave is seen on the left, in the range 50 m < x < 60 m, and the beam profile on the right. It can be seen how the flexural wave propagates along the beam from right to left before being reflected from the left-hand end back towards the right (and reducing in amplitude). The surface plots also make clear that the group velocity of the flexural wave in the beam is lower than that of the water wave.

caption.p: Spatial profiles of the wave packets and the beam at three times (case 4) for the PM spectra and the Gaussian spectra.
Space–time plots of (a) incident wave elevation and (b) beam deflection in case 4, for a PM wave group having a peak period of 2.69 s.

sec.p: The right-hand subplots in Figure 9 show the spatial profiles of the wave group based on the Gaussian spectrum, and the response of the case 4 beam, again at three times. These are: first, the time at which the wave comes into focus at the right-hand end of the beam; next, the time of the largest response at the left-hand end of the beam; and, finally, the time of the subsequent maximum response at the right-hand end. The latter is linked to the continuing large excitation from the incoming wave, rather than resulting primarily from a reflected wave in the beam as shown in the left-hand subplots of Figure 9. It is, however, clear from Figure 7(b) that damped reflected waves linked to resonance do indeed persist in the beam under the Gaussian wave group, well after the passage of the group itself.

sec.title: Discussion and conclusions
sec.p: A fundamental study was conducted of the response of a floating uniform elastic beam to regular wave groups and transient waves. The influences of the model parameters on the hydroelastic behaviour were investigated, with an emphasis on a broad range of parameters rather than on those related to any particular practical designs of current interest. It has been observed that the non-dimensional parameter μ, which is the draught of the floating beam divided by its length, appears to play a key role in the appearance of sharply peaked resonant responses.

A parameter which has been suggested in the literature as a useful indicator of hydroelastic response (see, for example, the report by Committee VI.2 of the International Ship and Offshore Structures Congress36) is the ratio of a characteristic (dimensional) length λC to the length λW of the freely propagating water wave. Here
in terms of the parameter β defined above. Hence

where k is the dimensionless water wavelength. An alternative indicative ratio can be written in terms of the (dimensional) elastic wavelength λE in the equivalent infinitely long floating beam. Based on the parameters used here, kE = 2πL/λE, where kE is the root of the equation28
It may be noted that values of λE/λW depend on both μ and β, whereas λC/λW depends only on β (and the water wave number in both cases).

Figure 11(a) shows λE/L versus λW/L for the four cases investigated above, plotted against the right-hand axis. The left-hand axis indicates the dimensionless deep-water wave number K. Also shown is the straight line along which the elastic wavelength λE is equal to the water wavelength λW. The values of λC/L are 0.294 for cases 1 and 3, and 0.167 for cases 2 and 4. Figure 11(b) shows the influence of the parameter β when μ is fixed at the value specified for case 1. It is found that changes to β, for beams either stiffer or more flexible than the reference case 1, in no case leads to a situation in which λE is less than λW in Figure 11(b). On the other hand, the larger value of μ corresponding to cases 3 and 4 in Figure 11(a) does indeed lead to a broad range of frequencies for which λE < λW. This would appear to be significant in relation to the resonances observed in Figure 5 and the transient behaviour shown in Figures 6 and 7.

caption.p: Dimensionless elastic wavelength λE/L versus dimensionless water wavelength λW/L: (a) cases 1 to 4; (b) for μ = 8.36 × 10−4 and four values of β. Also shown is the dimensionless deep-water wave number K.

sec.p: The significance of the elastic wavelength λE in this problem is further highlighted in the paper by Khabakhpasheva.37 She found that the responses of the beam are a maximum when the transmission coefficient of the wave incident on the beam has a maximum and that this occurs when the beam length is a multiple of the elastic wavelength (after making allowance for end effects in the finite-length beam). In the notation of the present paper, the elastic wave numbers corresponding to these maxima are approximated by

where N0 is the number of elastic waves within the plate away from the ends (integer values for anti-symmetric modes, and integer values plus 0.5 for symmetric modes). According to Khabakhpasheva,37 the end effects would be represented in the present context by a constant c which takes a value between 0.8 and 0.92. This has been investigated here for case 4. It is found that the best approximation is given using c = 0.92, the results for which are shown in Table 3. Here K0 is the deep-water gravity wave number corresponding to the approximation kE0. The last row in the table gives the real parts of the complex poles evaluated above, associated with the modes seen in Figure 3. It is apparent that the approximation improves with increasing N0 (i.e. in the higher modes of the beam). This is of course consistent with the fact that the wavelength λE is that of an elastic wave in an infinitely long plate, where there are no end effects.

caption.p: Approximations to the real part of the complex pole K¯r for case 4.

sec.p: In conclusion, it is worth drawing attention to the following points.

list-item.p: When sharply peaked resonances are observed in the frequency response functions, these are linked to the imaginary parts of the eigenvalues of the system matrix for the discretised model, which involves full coupling between the hydrodynamics and the structural dynamics of the beam.

If a beam exhibiting such steady state responses is excited by a wave packet originating in a sea state with a narrowband spectrum, the beam response may decay to zero over a much longer timescale than that of the incident wave packet.
Persistent reflections of travelling elastic waves within such a beam can be clearly observed if it is excited by a wave packet characterised by a broadband spectrum.

ack.p: The use of the approximation discussed in the fifth section was suggested by one of the anonymous referees, to whom thanks are due.

fn.p: This work was supported by the Centre for Offshore Research and Engineering at the National University of Singapore. Some of the material in this paper was first presented at the Workshop on Mathematical Challenges and Modelling of Hydroelasticity (21–24 June 2010), supported by the International Centre for Mathematical Sciences in Edinburgh.
